project.name: WLJ Secure Signup & Anti-Fraud System
project.description: Design and implement a layered, low-friction security system to prevent bot-driven and fraudulent account signups while preserving a smooth user experience for legitimate users.

description.objective: Identify and document all realistic signup abuse scenarios so defenses are intentional and measurable.
actions: List common signup threats (bot floods, disposable emails, proxy/VPN abuse, referral abuse).
For each threat, document impact to WLJ (cost, data quality, system stability).
Estimate likelihood (Low/Medium/High).
Map at least one primary mitigation per threat.
Store the threat model as a versioned markdown document.
description.output: A documented and versioned Signup Threat Model covering impact, likelihood, and mitigations.

tasks.name: Define Target Signup Flow with Progressive Friction

description.objective: Design a clear, step-by-step signup flow that increases friction only when risk signals appear.
actions: Define a pending account state prior to email verification.
Design a default low-friction path for low-risk users.
Insert invisible CAPTCHA triggered by suspicious behavior.
Define rate-limiting checkpoints in the flow.
Define optional phone verification for high-risk cases only.
Create a simple ASCII flow diagram documenting all paths.
description.output: A documented target signup flow with progressive friction and an ASCII flow diagram.

description.objective: Create a deterministic risk scoring system to classify signup attempts as low, medium, or high risk.
actions: List risk signals (IP reputation, signup speed, device reuse, disposable email domains).
Assign relative weights to each signal.
Define score thresholds for low, medium, and high risk.
Map enforcement actions to each risk tier.
Document the risk scoring logic clearly for engineers.
description.output: A documented and deterministic risk scoring model with clear thresholds and actions.

description.objective: Specify concrete, configurable security controls across application, infrastructure, identity, and monitoring layers.
actions: Define application-layer controls (form validation, honeypots, API validation).
Define infrastructure-layer controls (WAF rules, IP reputation, CDN bot protection).
Define identity-layer controls (password policy, email verification, MFA rules).
Define monitoring and response controls (logging, alerts, thresholds).
Document default recommended settings and explain why each control matters.
description.output: A complete checklist of layered security controls with defaults and rationale.

description.objective: Translate security design into implementation-ready specifications for engineers.
actions: Define required backend endpoints and fields (signup_attempt, risk_score, verification_status).
Specify which data must be stored and which must never be stored (privacy rules).
Define safe default rate limits with notes on tuning.
Specify email verification token rules (expiry, one-time use, rotation).
List approved third-party services for CAPTCHA, IP reputation, and WAF with use cases.
description.output: A clear, implementation-ready engineering specification for secure signup.

description.objective: Establish clear pass/fail rules to validate the effectiveness of signup security.
actions: Define acceptance criteria for bot flood protection.
Define acceptance criteria for email verification enforcement.
Define acceptance criteria for rate limiting behavior.
Define acceptance criteria for risk scoring outcomes.
Define acceptance criteria for logging and alert generation.
description.output: A complete set of measurable acceptance criteria for secure signup.

description.objective: Ensure signup defenses work correctly under normal and abusive conditions.
actions: Define manual test cases for real user signup scenarios.
Define automated unit and integration tests for signup logic.
Design abuse simulations (bot floods, rapid retries, proxy rotation).
Document expected outcomes for each test case.
description.output: A comprehensive signup security test plan with example test cases and expected results.

description.objective: Provide a clear, opinionated default configuration that can be deployed immediately.
actions: Summarize the recommended default signup security configuration.
Ensure defaults balance security and user experience.
Document configuration values in a single reference section.
Mark configuration as versioned and adjustable over time.
description.output: A final Recommended Default Configuration section ready for deployment.
